awd_titl_txt: SBE: Small: Behavioral Control of Deceivers in Online Attacks
awd_abstract_narration:
Online attacks can cause not only temporary asset loss, but long-term psychological or emotional harm to victims as well. The richness and large scale of online communication data open up new opportunities for detecting online attacks. However, attackers are motivated to constantly adapt their behaviors to changes in security operations to evade detection. Deception underlies most attacks in online communication, and people are poor at detecting deception. Against this backdrop, this project aims to improve the resilience of solutions to online attacks and enable predictive methods for their detection. Although a complete set of deception behaviors of online attackers is assumed to be unknown, there is a reason to expect that some behaviors are more difficult for attackers to control than others. By identifying such behaviors and their relations in online communication, the project lays the groundwork for the development of resilient and predictive approaches to the detection of online attacks, and advances the state of knowledge on online deception behavior and its identification. At the educational front, the project provides new educational material for enriching the curriculum in cyber security and related disciplines. The interdisciplinary nature of this work contributes to graduate student training toward a new generation of scientists who are capable of conducting multi-disciplinary cutting-edge research using a variety of research methods. The PIs actively engage students at both graduate and undergraduate levels in their research activities, particularly making a strong effort to engage women and underrepresented minorities.

Online attackers' evolving behaviors can make the existing solutions to online attacks become ineffective quickly. This project not only discovers new deception behaviors and their relations from the discourse and structure of online communication, but also determines attackers' behavioral control during online attacks by comparing different types of online deception behavior. Further, this project develops techniques for automatic extraction of deception behaviors from online communication by building upon natural language processing and network analysis techniques. Some anticipated advances include: (1) deception theory extension by investigating deception behavior in online attacks via a new lens of behavior control, (2) guidelines on how to improve the resilience of online attack detection methods by identifying deception behaviors that likely escape the attackers' control attempt, (3) a predictive approach to attack detection in online communication by exploring the temporal relationships among deception behaviors, and (4) techniques for extracting deception behaviors from online discourse and structure. This project can lead to integrative and effective methods for online attack detection.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we identified complex deception behavior or cues to deception from text-based online communication such as discourse, consistency, and structure. For instance, deception behavior can be embedded in discourse —an extended sequence of communicative interactions that go beyond the meaning of individual interactions. We also drew deception behavior from inconsistency, which could exist between different parts of a communication, between different communications in the same discourse, and between different communications from the same deceiver. Deception behavior can further be embedded in the network structure constructed from the communicative relationships in which the deceiver were involved.  The discovery of the complex deception behavior led to the identification of avoidance and protective strategies of deceivers.

We designed different types of training on online deception behavior, and examined their effects on human performance in phishing detection through a controlled lab experiment. Our results show that it is insufficient to provide users with deception behaviors, related descriptions, and illustrative examples only. Instead, an effective training should also include virtual or in-person lecture, practice, and even test. Topic familiarity showed a negative effect on the detection performance, suggesting that phishing detection is a challenging task that demands systematic processing. We deepened our knowledge on human susceptibility to online attacks by understanding the association of individuals' basic demographic characteristics with phishing victimization. The results show that males had a lower likelihood of phishing victimization than females; and technical experience have a negative effect on phishing victimization when the education level is low.

To facilitate automatic extraction of online deception behavior and factors contributing to information credibility, we advanced the techniques for extracting information from social media text. RubE consisted of unsupervised rule-based methods that extract both subjective and objective product features from online consumer reviews. The methods integrated semantic relationships, review-specific patterns, double propagation, indirect dependency, and comparative construction. RubE not only showed superior performance to the state-of-the-art techniques but also its generalizability across different types of products in our empirical evaluations. In addition, we proposed a weakly supervised WordNet-guided deep learning approach to extracting product feature expressions. It drew on deep-level semantic information from WordNet to guide both the selection of representative seed terms and the pruning of candidate terms for product features. The method consistently outperformed discrete models and the state-of-the-art continuous-space language models based on our comprehensive evaluations.

By leveraging the knowledge about deception behaviors and behavior extraction and machine learning techniques, we investigated deception detection in a variety of contexts, such as fake online reviewers, scan ads, phishing emails, fraudulent tweets, fake news, and online misinformation. We extended temporal and multi-level network analysis, and proposed and evaluated deep transfer learning approaches, for the prediction or detection of online attacks. Our research has improved the state-of-the-art detection performance and identified resilient online deception behavior.

This project lays the groundwork for resilient and predictive methods for detecting online attacks. The results of the work help address the cognitive and memory limitations and biases of everyday users and their poor performance in detecting online attacks. They will educate the public about their roles in countering online attacks as well as increase their awareness of complex deception behavior. Our findings on online deception behavior and techniques for information extraction were incorporated in undergraduate courses on social media analytics and applications and management information systems. We involved and trained one undergraduate female student and one Master’s student from underrepresented minorities in STEM, as well as four Ph.D. students. One of the Ph.D. students is now working at Apple. Two other students received the university Proposal Development Summer Fellowships. The undergraduate student  joined the graduate program at a top-30 national university. One of our papers received Best Paper Nomination at the 17th Workshop on Information Technologies and Systems. Our findings have been disseminated through 20 peer-reviewed publications in premier journals in multiple disciplines such as computer science and information systems, such as JMIS and ACM transactions, and a number of conferences on security.
